In the photo are members of the “One Word Organisation” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 3,400,000 SLL for the entire group in order to expand their businesses.
 
The leader of this group is Aminata.  Aminata is a native of Segbema. She is married to a trader and the couple has three children – two in primary school and one in secondary school. Aminata has been a businesswoman for three years now. She sells palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil). Aminata has requested this loan in order to buy gallons of palm oil to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy gallons of palm oil

loans.name: Tamarneh Ii Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the 'Tamarneh II' group from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their respective businesses, increase their sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Aminata is the featured leader of this group. The 45 year old is married to a businessman. Aminata has been a businesswoman for seven years; she sells groundnuts/peanuts and soap.  

With her share of this loan, she is going to a buy a large quantity of groundnuts and soap to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to a buy a large quantity of groundnuts and soap to add to her current stock

loans.name: Leh We Help Weself Group

texts.en:
Fanta is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fanta was born in Sandor, 56 years ago. She is married to a driver and the couple has four children who are attending primary and secondary school. Fanta sells slippers and flip-flops and has been doing business for seven years now. 

With the help of this loan, Fanta and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Fanta will use her share of the loan (SLL 800,000) to buy slippers and flip-flops in large quantity to add to her current stock. 

(Also attached to the right of the photo is a borrower who was not present for the group snap shot.)

loans.use: to buy slippers and flip-flops in large quantity to add to her current stock

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, rice, sugar, flour, etc.  in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Super Unit Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Super Unit” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are requesting a loan of 800,000 SLL for each in order to expand their respective businesses. 

The leader of this group is Jariatu. She is 47 years old and a native of Lunsar. She is married to a trader and the couple has five children – two in primary school and three in secondary school. Jariatu has been a businesswoman for seven years now. She sells cultural beads, chains, earrings, combs, mirrors, etc. Jariatu has requested this loan in order to buy cultural beads, chains, earrings, combs, mirrors, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy cultural beads, chains, earrings, combs, mirrors, etc.

loans.name: The United Women Group

texts.en:
Adama is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Adama was born in Gbene, 27 years ago. She is married to a diamond miner/businessman and the couple has two children – one in primary school and the other is too young for school. 

For the past two years, Adama has been selling market food – palm oil, onions, salt, pepper, sugar, flour, rice, etc. This is the first loan that Adama and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, increase their sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Adama will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) to buy palm oil, onions, salt, pepper, sugar, flour, rice, etc. at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, salt, pepper, sugar, flour, rice, etc. at wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for a chuff cutter

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La clienta vive en Guayaquil. Empezó  vendiendo especies en el norte oeste de  la ciudad, luego se cambio al suburbio y a podido crecer su clientela a quienes le vende los especies como aji, ajo, ajinomoto, sal.

Su dificultad es cuando tiene recaídas producto de su enfermedad ya que ella es pvvs (personas viviendo con vih sida) y la delincuencia q hay en el sector donde tiene su negocio.

Es soltera, no tiene hijos. Con el préstamo quiere comprar especies. Su sueño es disfrutar a sus seres queridos y distribuir las especies a más personas , tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
This borrower lives in Guayaquil. She began selling spices in the northwestern part of the city. She later moved to the suburbs and was able to grow her clientele. The borrower sells spices such as aji chili peppers, garlic, MSG, and salt.

Her difficulty is whenever she has a relapse of her illness. The borrower is a person living with HIV/AIDS. She must also deal with the presence of crime in the area where she has her business.

The borrower is single and has no children. She will use this loan to buy spices. Her dreams include enjoying the company of her loved ones, selling spices to more people, and having a house of her own.

loans.use: to buy spices such as aji chili peppers, garlic, MSG, and salt.

loans.name: Danayaa-Ii Group

texts.en:
Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Kiva.org in Makeni, northern Sierra Leone is very pleased to present to you members of the “Danayaa II” group. These are small-scale entrepreneurs who have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 800,000 for each in order to invest in their respective businesses. 

Magret is the featured leader of this group. Magret is a twenty-seven-year-old; she is married with four children – three in primary school and one in secondary school. Magret sells cigarettes, milk, sugar, batteries, soap, toothpaste, biscuits, sweets, books, etc. She has been a businesswoman for seven years now. With the help of this loan, Magret will invest in her business by buying the above-mentioned items in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy cigarettes, milk, sugar, batteries, soap, toothpaste, biscuits, sweets, books, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Abu

texts.en:
Presented to you in the photo above is Abu, a machine operator at a sugar producing company in Sierra Leone. The 31-year-old machine operator is married to a businesswoman and the couple has four children, one of whom is attending primary school; the rest are still not of school-going age.

Abu has been working at the sugar company for six years now. With this loan, Abu is going to buy house-building materials like corrugated iron sheets, cement, nails, etc. for the construction of a dwelling house for his family.

loans.use: to buy house-building materials like corrugated  iron sheets, cement, nails, etc. for the construction of a dwelling house for his family

loans.name: Abiut

texts.en:
Abiut lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which is an area with high poultry production and consumption. He has three children, and has been doing this work for four years.  His primary income sources are eggs, crops, and salary from a job. He will use the loan to buy poultry birds.

He said that "poultry keeping!" is what is most enjoyable about farming. His biggest challenge is "poultry diseases and expensive poultry feeds".

Abiut was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, and he replied, "Because Juhudi  gives loans to farmers at favorable terms..".  This client was also asked what he learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session, "There are loans given to farmers or small scale entrepreneurs".

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Abiut replied, "Income from the poultry project will help me educate my children".

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Abiut owns the following: poultry and bicycle, but does not own a cow, pig, pump, motorcycle, or automobile.  Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, a TV, or a DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, increasing efficiency, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which is an area with high poultry production and consumption. He has four children and has been doing this work for 11 years.  His primary income sources are eggs, crops, and transportation services. He will use the loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

Robert stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Dairy keeping and poultry keeping!' His biggest challenge is 'Animal diseases." One animal in the farm is named 'Maua.'

Robert was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'Because Juhudi Kilimo gives loans to farmers to finance their activities.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'The various assets being financed by Juhudi Kilimo and the importance of directing funds to the intended projects.'

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Robert replied 'Income from the sale of milk will boost my other sources of income so as to educate my children and provide my family with other needs.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Robert owns the following: 'poultry, bicycle' but does not own 'cow, pig, pump, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Pictured above is a staff member of a sugar producing company in Sierra Leone. He has come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of SLL 3,000,000 in order to meet his most immediate and most pressing financial needs. And the end of each month, he can easily repay the loan, using his monthly salary. It is the company’s financial manager who deducts his repayments and repays SMT/Kiva lenders on his behalf. 

He is Mohamed, a 51-year-old man from Portloko, in northern Sierra Leone. Mohamed is married to a businesswoman and the two of them have five children, four of whom are attending primary school. Mohamed has worked in the sugar company for 10 years. In addition to his work at the company, he is also a businessman. He produces and sells 'gara' cloth (locally dyed cloth).

 With the help of this loan, Mohamed is going to buy 'gara'-producing materials like ink, caustic soda, powder, etc. for the production of a larger quantity of 'gara' cloth for sale.

loans.use: to buy 'gara'-producing materials like ink, caustic soda, powder, etc. for the production of a larger quantity of 'gara' cloth for sale

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which has a high regional output of maize. He has five children and has been doing this work for 10 years.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'poultry keeping!'.  His biggest challenge is 'Diseases and expensive poultry feed". One animal in the farm is named."Maua". He will use the loan of 30,000 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds.

Francis was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'Because Juhudi finances farmers to boost their lives..'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'They are short-term loans.'

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Francis replied 'I will get income for the upkeep of my family and to pay for school fees for my children.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Francis owns the following: 'cow, poultry, motorcycle' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, electricity, TV, DVD' but does not have 'solar power, running water, sewing machine'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds

Kisiero lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which is an area with high poultry production and consumption. He has four children and has been doing this work for 10 years.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "feeding and milking dairy cows".His biggest challenge is "animal diseases". He will use the loan of 62,400 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

Kisiero was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'Because Juhudi Kilimo offers loans to farmers at a lower interest rate.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'They are short-term loans.'

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Kisiero replied, 'I will be able to generate money to educate and take good care of my children.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Kisiero owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

loans.name: Carison

texts.en:
Carison lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which has a high regional output of maize. He has two children and has been doing this work for 11 years.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Dairy farming!' His biggest challenge is "dairy animal diseases". He will use the loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

Carison was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'Juhudi Kilimo tries to improve the lives of farmers by giving loans to smallholder farmers." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'How to use the money borrowed from Juhudi Kilimo to avoid defaulting.'

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Carison replied, "I will get money from selling milk so as to supplement my income and provide basic needs to my family".

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Carison owns the following: 'cow, poultry, bicycle' but does not own 'pig, pump, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, where available land is scarce. She has three children and has been doing this work for five years.  Her primary income sources are milk and crops. She will use the loan of 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Gets money to use with the family!' Her biggest challenge is 'Too much rain.' Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Kadogo' and 'Maridadi.'

Gladys was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: "having funding for dairy cows".  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'Helps one get a cow on credit.'

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Gladys replied 'Milk for the family.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Gladys owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, running water' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.name: Nyandieka

texts.en:
Nyandieka lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, where available land is scarce. He has no children and has been doing this work for three years.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, tea, and his job salary. He will use the loan of 36,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "earnings out of farming produce". His biggest challenge is 'Diseases'. One of his animals is named 'Smart.'

Nyandieka was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: 'Quick to give money out.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'Helps the people of low income.'

His highest monthly expense is farming costs. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Nyandieka replied 'Dairy cow.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Nyandieka owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net, running water' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.name: Nicodemus

texts.en:
Nicodemus lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is primarily a region growing bananas and sugar cane. He has 2 children and has been doing this work for 4 years. His primary income sources are eggs and personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming:"Good harvest!" His biggest challenges are animal diseases. The animal on the farm is named "Nyangera."

Nicodemus was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "It serves everyone." This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: "The easy availability of loans."

His highest monthly expense is business related. When asked "How will this loan benefit your family?", Nicodemus replied "It will allow us to buy a dairy cow."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Nicodemus owns  a cow and some poultry, but does not own pigs, a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net and running water, but does not have electricity, solar power, a sewing machine, a TV, or a DVD player. 

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is an area that does not suffer from a dry season. He has six children and has been doing this work for five years.  His primary income sources are crops.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming:"earning profit".His biggest challenge is 'lack of capital for large-scale farming".

James was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "to buy a dairy cow".This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'Help one to advance.'

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', James replied "acquisition of poultry and a dairy cow to provide income and milk for family consumption".

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. James owns the following: 'cow' but does not own 'pig, poultry, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Edda Ramona

texts.es:
Edda, una señora de 48 años de edad , madre de tres hijos, todos mayores de edad , toda su familia junto con ella viven en Managua , ella tiene una pulpería y venta de tortillas. Su primer negocio fue la venta de tortillas comenzó con un horno artesanal con la ganancia que le generaba las tortillas compro una mantenedora usada para vender hielo, leche, refrescos poco a poco fue agregando más productos hasta formar su pulpería. Actualmente su esposo la apoya con lo que gana para aportar a los gastos del hogar y al misma vez cuidar la pulpería cuando ella sale a vender tortillas.  
Ella está solicitando el financiamiento para comprar leña, maíz, gaseosa, granos básicos, queso, crema, huevos, pan, leche, productos de limpieza etc. En sus planes futuro desea compara estantes para exhibir sus productos, mejorar la infraestructura de su hogar para tener un techo digno donde vivir.
texts.en:
Edda, 48, is a mother of three children, all of whom are adults. The entire family lives together in Managua. 

She has a small grocery store and she also sells tortillas. Her first business was selling tortillas, which she started with a handmade oven. With her profits from the tortilla sales, she bought a refrigerator to sell ice, milk, and soft drinks. Little by little, she continued to add more products until she opened her grocery store. Her husband supports her with his salary to contribute to the home expenses, and he also takes care of the grocery store when she goes out to sell tortillas.

She has applied for a loan to buy firewood, corn, soft drinks, basic grains, cheese, cream, eggs, bread, milk, cleaning products, etc. In the future, she hopes to buy shelves to exhibit her products and to improve the infrastructure of her home in order to have a decent place to live.

loans.use: to buy firewood, corn, soft drinks, basic grains, cheese, cream, eggs, bread, milk, cleaning products, etc.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which has a high regional output of maize. He has two children and has been doing this work for eight years.  His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops, and personal business. He will use the loan of KES 35,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy poultry birds.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "Poultry keeping!" His biggest challenge is "poultry diseases."

Emmanuel was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Because it offers loans to farmers at a lower interest rate."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi Kilimo's required microfinance training session: "Importance of directing loans to the intended projects."

His highest monthly expense is business-related. When asked "How will this loan benefit your family?," Emmanuel replied, "Money from the poultry project will help me to expand my farming activities and pay school fees for my children."

As part of Juhudi Kilimo's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Emmanuel owns the following: 'cow, poultry, bicycle,' but does not own: 'pig, pump, motorcycle, automobile.' Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards, based on this loan. This borrower has in the household: 'mosquito net,' but does not have: 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD.'

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard lives in the Litein area of Kenya, which houses Mt. Kenya University. He has no children. He has been doing dairy-farming work for 10 years.  His primary income sources are milk and eggs. He will use the loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy a dairy cow.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming is "dairy farming." His biggest challenges are "unstable market prices and a lack of enough capital to expand the business." One of the animals on his farm is named "Tuiyai."

Benard was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Low rates and it is faster."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session. He replied, "They are good for our economy."

His highest monthly expenses are his farming costs. When asked how this loan will benefit his family, Benard replied, "It will help me generate more income for my family."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Benard owns a cow and poultry but does not own a pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle or automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in his household a mosquito net and solar power but does not have electricity, running water, sewing machine, TV or DVD player.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and then sent the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Josephat

texts.en:
Josephat lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is not far from Masai land. He has one child and has been doing his work for five years.  His primary income sources are milk, crops, and personal business.

He stated what is most enjoyable about farming: "High yields!" His biggest challenge is: "Hailstones." Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Maridadi.' He will use the loan of KES 62,400 from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

Josephat was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which he replied: "Help me advance in farming."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi Kilimo's required microfinance training session: "Get credit loan to do business."

His highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked, "How will this loan benefit your family?," Josephat replied, "Milk."

As part of Juhudi Kilimo's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Josephat owns the following: 'cow,' but does not own: 'pig, poultry, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile.' 

Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards, based on this loan. This borrower has in the household: 'mosquito net, solar power, TV, DVD,' but does not have: 'electricity, running water, sewing machine.'

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy merchandise and equipment to begin selling sweets and flavored drinks.

loans.name: Saad

texts.en: Saad is a married man with eight children, living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has been operating a retail shop and also has rental houses from which he earns a monthly income from rental collections. Late rent payments and price fluctuations affect the growth of his businesses, while his dream is to own a housing estate and a wholesale business. Saad is requesting a loan to buy general merchandise for his shop such as salt and soap.

loans.use: to buy general merchandise such as salt and soap to sell.

loans.name: Magdalena Del Rosario

texts.es:
Magdalena es una mujer de 24 años, es soltera, vive en la ciudad de Ica con sus padres y su pequeña hija, a quien ama y es su principal razón en la vida, ella es una persona muy amable, trabajadora y entusiasta, que dedica todos sus esfuerzos por sacar adelante a su pequeña, ya que ella es padre y madre para su pequeña; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tuvo de trabajar desde muy joven, Magdalena no pudo estudiar la carrera profesional de Enfermería que deseaba, en sus ratos libres el gusta jugar con su pequeña y en algunas ocasiones cocina una riquísima Carapulcra con Sopa Seca para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Magdalena trabaja en su pequeño negocio de venta de lentes, monturas y lentes de sol, adicionalmente tiene un taxi, el cual alquila a choferes para que brinden servicios de transporte en su ciudad, ella trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 12 horas y cree que le va bien por los buenos precios y por el trato amable que brinda a sus clientes.
Magdalena se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la refacción y el mantenimiento general que necesita su taxi, de esta manera Magdalena tendrá su herramienta de trabajo en mejores condiciones, así pues ella seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de tener una óptica y su propia casa.
texts.en:
Magdalena, 24, is single and lives in the city of Ica with her parents and her young daughter, whom she loves and who is her main reason for living. She is a very friendly, hardworking, and enthusiastic person who dedicates all of her efforts towards providing for her daughter, since she is both mother and father to her. 

Unfortunately, due to a lack of resources and the need to begin working at a young age, Magdalena was not able to study a professional career in nursing as she would have liked. In her free time, she likes to play with her daughter and sometimes she cooks a delicious Carapulcra con Sopa Seca (a traditional Peruvian stew) to share with her family.

By her own initiative and with plenty of effort and dedication, Magdalena works in her small business selling lenses, frames, and sunglasses. She also has a taxi which she rents out to drivers so they can offer transport services in the city. She works every day for about 12 hours per day, and she believes that her work is going well because of the good prices and friendly service which she offers to her clients.

Magdalena is very grateful to the Kiva lenders because thanks to their help, she will be able to buy spare parts and perform essential maintenance on her taxi. Her taxi will then be in better condition, so she will be able to continue working and putting in effort to achieve her great dream of having an optician's shop and her own house.

loans.use: to buy replacement parts and perform maintenance on her taxi.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a 29-year-old, married man living in Kasese, Uganda. He has one child. Being a good father, he dreams of educating his child (and any future children he may have) up to the University level, and of constructing a permanent house for his family's residence.

For three years he has been selling electronics, but he also has other income sources, such as cassava flour selling, motorcycle transport and a salt pan business. Price fluctuations and inadequate capital pose challenges to his goals, including his desire to expand his transport and electronics businesses. Julius intends to use the loan to buy a motorcycle, which he will hire out to a driver who will remit 80% of the daily earnings to him.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.name: Januka Malla

texts.en:
Januka is 40 years old and is married with one child, aged 21. In 2000, she established her grocery store business and by working seven days a week, 12 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid six loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent one to buy groceries for her business. 

In the future, Januka plans to improve the financial situation of her family and she thanks you for your support. In the Kathmandu Valley where she lives, small grocery stores, called pasals, are an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils, and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping their inventories strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 square feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce, and shrewd businesswomen.

loans.use: to buy groceries for her store

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth is a 50-year-old, married woman living in Kasese, Uganda. She has five children. Eighteen years ago, she decided to join government service after qualifying as a nurse. With savings from her salary, she has been able to buy land for farming. She says that, with the current inflation, her salary can hardly meet her basic needs. Her dream is to educate her children up to the University level. Ruth intends to use the loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to pay for school fees for her children.

loans.name: Sani

texts.en:
Sani is 40 years old.  She is married and has two children, aged 20 and 17.  In 2005, she established her business, raising dairy cows.  Working seven days a week and four hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received, and successfully repaid, six loans from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buy a young, milk-giving cow.  Sani plans to uplift the economic condition of her family, in the future.  She thanks you for your support.

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal.  Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk, from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made.  Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking.  On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day.  In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50.  In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung, which is used in home construction and as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks.  The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will pay for itself, many times over.

loans.use: to buy a young, milk-giving cow

loans.name: Rama

texts.en:
Rama is 50 years old.  She is married and has two children aged 24 and 22.  In 2002, she established  her poultry farming business.  Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid six loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buy chicks to raise for her business. 

 In the future, Rama plans to uplift the economic conditions of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

In the Kathmandu Valley, raising poultry for eggs and meat is a very profitable business.  Kiva loans are used to purchase chicks, food, and necessary medicine to keep the chickens healthy.  Once mature, the chickens are sold at small butcher shops or in the many open air markets throughout the valley.

loans.use: to buy chicks to raise

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
This is 48-year-old Ellen.  She is married and has one child aged 28. She has two additional dependents, who live with her as sales assistants.  In 1997, Ellen established her drinks business. She began her business because she wanted to assist her husband in their family affairs. Her business is located on the outskirts of the town and her main customers are men and women. 

Working 7 days a week and 15 hours a day, she earns about Le 800,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000. Ellen requires a loan in order to plough into her business. She hopes that this loan will support her  through its proper use. In the future, Ellen plans to erect a guest house for her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more drinks for resale
